properties.about: A 40-mile stretch of the Verde is designated as a ―Wild and Scenic River (one of only two such designations in Arizona). the Verde watershed is one of Arizona’s most important water-producing areas, supporting significant riparian habitat – including one of the last Fremont cottonwood/Goodding willow forests in Arizona. Habitat along the Verde and its tributaries supports: - Over 200 bird species, including the largest number of bald eagle nesting sites in Arizona; - One of the most diverse native fish populations in Arizona, including the endangered Razorback Sucker; - Populations of river otter (which to date are found in only three Arizona rivers) and beavers, which are returning to the Verde and restoring watershed health through dam-building activities; and - Large populations of elk, deer, bear, and mountain lions in the higher elevations of the watershed. Learn more
The San Pedro is one of the last undammed desert river in the American Southwest. In 1988, Congress created the San Pedro Riparian National Conservation Area. Learn more
The Wind River's stunning granite peaks are a rock climbers paradise.
This cowboy/ski town at the headwaters of the Yampa River is known for it's beauty, champagne powder and great summer tubing!

properties.photo credit: InSapphoWeTrust from Los Angeles, California, USA
properties.about: Dinosaur footprints, yes, but also one of the most spectacular white water canyons anywhere in the West!
Float through this slow-moving, calm water section of the Green River just West of Canyonlands National Park to be emerged in history and geology. Learn more
West of Canyonlands National Park lies this remote and beautiful desert canyon.

Located near the San Juan River, this tiny town of less than 300 residents has an interesting history.  It was settled by mormon pioneers in the 1800s and historic homes from that era are still visible today. From town visitors can see two interesting rock formations - Locomotive Rock and Twin Rocks.

Very arid land draining north into the San Juan and south into the Little Colorado. Home to ancient pueblo cultures (ancestors of Hopi) and, for past 500 years, the Navajos who moved from the north. Lots of interesting grazing and mining issues and well as the Navajo Generating Station (huge coal plant) just outside Paige, AZ.
properties.point of interest: Navajo and Hopi lands (northeast corner of AZ)

properties.about: This rich wilderness is home to hot springs and, recently, huge fires. Nature writer and conservationist Aldo Leopold helped to get the Gila Wilderness designated the world's first wilderness area on June 3, 1924.

This desert river is a major tributary to the Colorado River. Waters in the river's lower reaches are fed by Blue Springs complex. Waters are heavily mineralized water and contain travertine deposits. The river starts high in the mountains at  Baldy Peak in eastern Arizona.
These oft photographed falls located in a slot canyon off of the Grand Canyon are known for their beauty and mineral-rich bright blue waters.
Waters rush over 600 foot cliffs,  wind through Emerald Cave, and flow by natural hot springs. The canyon narrows at one point to only 40 meter wide.

The Virgin river flows uninterrupted from its headwaters above Zion National Park to Lake Mead. Segments of the River and some tributaries within Zion Park are part of the Federal Wild and Scenic River System. The gorge, between St. George Utah and Littlefield, Arizona transitions from the Colorado Plateau to the Mojave Desert.
This incredible river system is full of spectacular sandstone side canyons and rich paleohistory. It flows into Lake Powell.

The Paria River flows from Utah to the Colorado River at Lees Ferry, Arizona. This incredible area narrows to a slot canyon with sheer cliffs up to 1,000 feet high. Buckskin Gulch is considered one of the longest and deepest slot canyons in the United States.

This wildlife refuge is an important landing spot for migratory birds, specifcially the endangered southwestern will flycatcher. Located in the southwest corner of the United States, it also provides habitat for the destert Bighorn Sheep and contains the rare Topock Marsh. Stretching along the lower Colorado though the 20-mile long Topock Gorge, the refuge protects 30 miles of river habitat.

The Bill Williams River National Wildlife Refuge is located at the confluence with Lake Havasu and protects one of the last stands of natural cottonwood-willow habitat along the lower Colorado River, protecting several endangered species as well.The blend of upland desert, marsh and desert riparian habitat provides for a diversity of species.
properties.point of interest: Bill Williams River National Wildlife Refuge

properties.about: This refuge is the last unchannelized section of the river before it enters Mexico. It is a site of restoration efforts to maintain habitat for wintering migratory birds, protecting 30 miles of habitat along the lower Colorado River. The Imperial National Wildlife Refuge is associated with backwater lakes and wetalnds, allowing for a green oasis among desert mountains.

This place of interest was was a focal point for pre-historic and historic travel by tribal people, Spanish explorers, California gold seekers and immigrants, where two granite outcroppings along the Colorado allowed for a narrowing fomation of the river for a thousand miles.

Glenwood Canyon, located upstream of Glenwood Spgs, CO, has a full length bike path along the river, amazing scenery, rafting, and was an engineering marvel when they built the highway in the 1970s. In fact, the engineers had to transport a special bridge building machine from Europe in order to create the roadway. Hanging Lake is a popular hike with trailhead located just off the highway.

properties.photo credit: E. O. (Elias Olcott) Beaman, James Fennemore andJohn K. Hillers
properties.about: Gates of the Lodore is the northern river entrance to Dinosaur National Monument on the Green River. This point of interest is excellent for rafting, with tall canyon formations on each side of the river, making one feel as though they've entered the bowels of the Earth.

In Southwest Colorado, immerse yourself in some of the closest together, sheer vertical walls in the United States at Black Canyon, a big rock climbing destination. Western Resource Advocates has been involved in securing water rights for the park.
properties.point of interest: Black Canyon of the Gunnison National Park

properties.about: Located in the northcentral part of Colorado, Rocky Mountain National Park offers breathtaking mountain vistas, excellent trails for hiking and camping, and a diversity of wildlife in climates that range from wooded forest to mountain tundra. Within the park, the Continental Divide drives the direction of waterflow, including headwaters of the Colorado River.

The confluence of the Colorado and Little Colorado Rivers is located inside of Grand Canyon National Park. Where the rivers converge, there is a noticeable contrast in the color of each one, resulting in a cool glacial blue-white color from the two mixing. The Little Colorado River appears light brown, which is caused by recent cloudbursts. The Colorado is a light green color, which is caused by the Glen Canyon Dam trapping sediment.
properties.point of interest: Confluence of Colorado and Little Colorado Rivers –

properties.about: The homestead, where only two adobe walls remain, marks the birthplace of Cesar Chavez, American farmworker, labor leader, and civil rights activist. He spent his first 11 years here, working near the banks of the river.

Lake Mead was formed by the Hoover Dam and is the largest reservoir in the United States in it's maxiumum water capacity. The reservoir is 500 feet deep at its greatest depth, holds 28 million acre feet when filled to its capacity, but it hasn't reached that mark since 1983 due to droughts. Lake Mead is located 24 miles southeast of Las Vegas.

The second largest man-made reservoir in the United States, Lake Powel stores about 24,000 acre feet of water at its capacity. The reservoir was created by the flooding of Glen Canyon after the Glen Canyon Dam was made, and it has since become a popular tourist destination. It is located on the border of Utah and Arizona, and in addition to recreation, the reservoir serves as a storage facility for the Upper Basin states of the Colorado River Compact.

Glen Canyon is located north of the Grand Canyon in the Vermillion cliffs area. Much of the canyon was destroyed upon completion of the controversial Glen Canyon Dam in 1963. The flooding of Glen Canyon led to the formation of Lake Powell.

Hoover Dam is a major source of hydroelectric power for public and private utilities in Nevada, Arizona, and California. Constructed duing the Great Depression, the dam was massive effort to put individuals to work and was completed in 1936. It is located in Black Canyon along the Colorado River and impounds Lake Mead, which has been below its water capacity since 1983.

This is an important site on the Colorado River, and during the 1800's a ferry took people across the mighty river. It is the point that seperates the Upper and Lower Colorado River Basins, It is also a popular boat launch.
Rocky Mountain National Park is the headwaters of the Colorado River.
Wind River Range
The Colorado River once flowed into the Gulf of California (Sea of Cortez). Today the river, which at one point formed a vast estuary, is barely a trickle by the time it reaches the delta.
